name: Red-and-Green Macaw
description: The second-largest parrot (after the hyacinth macaw), it is predominantly red and blue. Distinctive features include green wing coverts forming clear bands on the wings and red streaks around the bare eye area. The upper beak is horn-colored, while the lower beak and legs are dark gray.
food_note: Nuts, seeds, soft fruits, shoots, buds
image_alt: Red-and-green macaw, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 29–42 cm; tail length 44–53 cm; wingspan up to 125 cm; weight 0.9–1.7 kg
reproduction: Females lay 1–3 eggs; incubation lasts 24–26 days.
attractions: They live in pairs that join flocks, sometimes with other macaw species. Females lay eggs in tree hollows, sharing incubation and chick-rearing duties with their partner. They can live up to 50 years.
breeding: Red-and-green macaws are a traditional species at Prague Zoo. The first lived there from 1936 to 1948. Another arrived in 1956 and long held the record as one of the zoo’s longest-kept animals, dying in 2008. Since 1991, many more have passed through the zoo. The first chick was successfully raised in 1993. Currently, we keep two young birds that arrived in 2009 from a private breeder.
